 Looking into the past, any numbskull can see that if there's one thing constant about organized religion, it's change. Religions evolve. They change (mutate, if you will), they die. It is not reasonable to assume that Christianity, Islam or any of the other current world religions will survive indefinitely in their present form. So where does religion go from here? 
 
 Of course the nature of evolution, both genetic and social, is not one that's predictable, but that shouldn't stop us from making some guesses, right? I'll start:
 
 I predict organized religion will have to depend much less heavily on their rulebooks, such as the Bible, Koran, Talmud, etc., leading to a much more spiritual, and less "Thou shalt..." experience. This will be because of science slowly chipping away at those areas previously only touched by those books.
 
 Looking even farther ahead....
 
 It is my feeling (not based on any particular piece of evidence), that although there will always be factionalizations, different groups, sects, whatever, that all religions will eventually have to meld into one if we're going to beat the dinosaur's record of inhabiting this planet. I wonder what that religion might look like....
 
 Alll this said, I should note that I don't in fact believe in any religion, but I tend to think it's necessary for large scale social cohesion. That may be a discussion for another time, though.
